medical_history.chief_complaint: Chest pain, lightheadedness, and vasovagal syncope.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient is a 40-year-old man who was admitted with new symptoms including chest pain, lightheadedness, and vasovagal syncope. He has a history of renal insufficiency, noted with a serum creatinine of 2.4 mg/dl, and has experienced incapacitating peripheral neuropathy characterized by bilateral severe stabbing pain and decreased skin sensation. GI symptoms included early satiety, nausea after meals, vomiting, abdominal bloating, and dysphagia, with neuropathy improving on gabapentin. His renal function gradually worsened over two months, prompting a kidney biopsy.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy diagnosed 6 years prior, gout, chronic indomethacin use, anemia, and renal insufficiency.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's mother carries the LYZ p.Leu102Ser variant but without clinical manifestations of amyloidosis. No other significant family medical history noted, except that a child has GI symptoms and undefined autoimmune disease.
